p.s: In textile factories all over the world workers are suffering and working hard for us to get the newest clothes.
But how bad is it really and what can we do against it.

In the newspaper article Fast fashion: Unser Kleiderkonsum ist Wahnsinn published in the germanGerman magazine Der Spiegel on 21 December 2017 the author Jörg Oberwittler interviews a woman named Imke Müller-Hellmann, who flew arund the world to learn about the working conditions of workers in textile factories.
She tells us about the around 3500 factories in and around Dhaka in Bangladesh and how they all throw their trash in one lake near the city.
The lake is black and therthere are hills of trash towering at the sides.
But not only the nature but also the workers are suffering.
They work for 12 hours a day, 6-7 days a week and they only do one step of a manufacturing process.
This work is very monotonous and the workers rarely get a day off.

Mrs. Müller-Hellmann also reports, that the workers are proud of themselfesthemselves if they get 300 boxershortsboxers done in one hour and that they don't even take breaks even if they are allowed to.
With this behaviour you see that most of the workers are already used to working only.
But what can you do to help the workers?
First of all you should not boycott products from bangladeshBangladesh since itsit's the major part of income the whole land gets.
You should instead pay intention to the labels that try to improve the working conditions.
And you should also criticise the standards that are manifested into our society.
In summary you should inform yourself more about the quality of workers life and try to help them as much as you can by informing others.
